title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Mozambique in 2020
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). As part of DSSI, China Eximbank and the Government of Mozambique signed a debt suspension agreement during calendar year 2020 (most likely between May 2020 and July 2020). Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between May 1, 2020 and December 31, 2020 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount is $20,860,216.77. However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period).   The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement. The lender and the borrower agreed that the repayment of the suspension amount for each loan agreement would take place in equal, successive, and semi-annual installments during a 3-year repayment period after a 1-year grace period (starting from and including the repayment date/repayment date of principal and interest falling within the suspension period). Additionally, under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of Mozambique. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0. 2. The total estimated suspension amount in 2020 is based on the amount reported in the Finance Ministry's Annual Public Debt Report for Fiscal Year 2020 (Relatório Anual da Dívida Pública - Exercício Fiscal 2020).
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Mozambique in 2020

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). As part of DSSI, China Eximbank and the Government of Mozambique signed a debt suspension agreement during calendar year 2020 (most likely between May 2020 and July 2020). Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between May 1, 2020 and December 31, 2020 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount is $20,860,216.77. However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period).   The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement. The lender and the borrower agreed that the repayment of the suspension amount for each loan agreement would take place in equal, successive, and semi-annual installments during a 3-year repayment period after a 1-year grace period (starting from and including the repayment date/repayment date of principal and interest falling within the suspension period). Additionally, under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
justification: Debt service suspension agreement with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Debt suspension agreement, focus on financial obligations and COVID-19 response

title: Chinese Government donates surgical masks and buses to the Government of Mozambique
description: On June 5, 2020, the Chinese government provided a donation of 10,000 surgical masks and 8 buses to the Government of Mozambique. The surgical masks were intended for COVID-19 prevention while the buses were intended to help transport government officials. Mozambique Minister Verónica Macamo Dhlovo and Chargé d'Affaires of the Government of the People's Republic of China in Maputo represented their countries at the signing of the Certificate of Delivery and reception of the donation ceremony.
staff_comments: 1. CRS coded as '430 - Other Multisector' because the donation consisted of COVID-19 relief and transportation assistance.AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER MULTISECTOR

# Title
Chinese Government donates surgical masks and buses to the Government of Mozambique

# Description
On June 5, 2020, the Chinese government provided a donation of 10,000 surgical masks and 8 buses to the Government of Mozambique. The surgical masks were intended for COVID-19 prevention while the buses were intended to help transport government officials. Mozambique Minister Verónica Macamo Dhlovo and Chargé d'Affaires of the Government of the People's Republic of China in Maputo represented their countries at the signing of the Certificate of Delivery and reception of the donation ceremony.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies and transportation equipment without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: 10,000 surgical masks for COVID-19 prevention, 8 buses for government transport

title: Chinese Government donates $107,000-worth of rice to displaced people in Cabo Delgado, Mozambique
description: On November 20, 2020 a ceremony was held for the donation of $107,000 (120 tons)-worth of rice from the Chinese Government to the Government of Mozambique. The donation was intended to provide food assistance to displaced people living in the Cabo Delgado province of Mozambique.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
Chinese Government donates $107,000-worth of rice to displaced people in Cabo Delgado, Mozambique

# Description
On November 20, 2020 a ceremony was held for the donation of $107,000 (120 tons)-worth of rice from the Chinese Government to the Government of Mozambique. The donation was intended to provide food assistance to displaced people living in the Cabo Delgado province of Mozambique.
justification: Project is focused on humanitarian food aid without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Food donation for displaced people, humanitarian assistance focus

title: Chinese Government funds surgical center in Maputo, Mozambique
description: In February 2020, it was reported that the Chinese Government would assist in funding a $40 million surgical center at Maputo Central Hospital. The hospital is said to be eight stories with 600 beds. The financial support was announced through Rádio Moçambique by the Chinese Ambassador to Mozambique. According to media sources, the surgical center was completed before 04/24/2020.
staff_comments: 1. It is unclear what portion of the needed USD 40 million China provided and if the support was through loans or grants.
combined_text:

# Title

In February 2020, it was reported that the Chinese Government would assist in funding a $40 million surgical center at Maputo Central Hospital. The hospital is said to be eight stories with 600 beds. The financial support was announced through Rádio Moçambique by the Chinese Ambassador to Mozambique. According to media sources, the surgical center was completed before 04/24/2020.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare infrastructure with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Surgical center at Maputo Central Hospital, healthcare focus, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Sichuan Province Government donates anti-epidemic supplies to Maputo Central Hospital
description: On September 3, 2020, a handover ceremony was held for the donation of medical supplies, which included 20,000 surgical masks, 5,000 N85 masks, 500 sets of overalls, and 300 sets of face shields, from Sichuan's Provincial Government to Maputo Central Hospital.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.

title: CNPC donates 100,000 surgical masks to Mozambique's Ministry of Health
description: On July 17, 2020, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) provided a donation of 100,000 surgical masks to Mozambique's Ministry of Health.
staff_comments: 1. ProjectID#92129 captures CNPC's subsequent donation of 15,000 masks to Mozambique INP, ProjectID#92130 captures the further donation of 40,000 masks to Mozambique MIREME, and ProjectID#92134 captures a subsequent CNPC donation of masks to Mozambique's ENH.AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.

title: Chinese Government donates anti-epidemic equipment to the Government of Mozambique
description: Before June 3, 2020, an unspecified sector within the Chinese Government provided its first donation of anti-epidemic equipment to the Government of Mozambique. A specific first donation has not been identified, but as ProjectID#91935 records a "second donation" of COVID-19 supplies, this project functions as a placeholder for the "first donation".
staff_comments: 1. While no specific first batch of supplies has been identified, this project serves as a placeholder. While the second batch of donations was widely reported on Chinese government websites, but the first was not, so the specific date when the donation occurred is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title

# Description
Before June 3, 2020, an unspecified sector within the Chinese Government provided its first donation of anti-epidemic equipment to the Government of Mozambique. A specific first donation has not been identified, but as ProjectID#91935 records a "second donation" of COVID-19 supplies, this project functions as a placeholder for the "first donation".
justification: Project involves donation of medical equipment for public health purposes, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Anti-epidemic equipment donation, healthcare sector focus
